docs.lead_paragraph: After four months of incessant Democratic pressure, the Senate approved a bill today to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15, virtually assuring a 90-cent-per-hour pay increase to more than 10 million Americans. The final vote was 74 to 24, with 27 Republicans joining all 47 Democrats in favor. But the crucial vote came earlier, on a Republican amendment that would have exempted many employers from paying the increased wage. Five Republicans, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, broke ranks to join all 47 Democrats.

headline.main: SENATE PASSES BILL FOR RAISE, TO $5.15, IN MINIMUM WAGE

docs.snippet: After four months of incessant Democratic pressure, the Senate approved a bill today to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15, virtually assuring a 90-cent-per-hour pay increase to more than 10 million Americans.         The final vote was 74 to...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than half a year after Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his budget and precisely 14 weeks after the state's fiscal year began on April 1, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders can confidently agree on one thing: the longest budget fight in New York State history no longer has much to do with the budget itself. Aides to Albany's ruling triumvirate -- the Governor, the Senate majority leader and the Assembly Speaker -- acknowledge that the things once considered great obstacles to a budget agreement, including overall spending, welfare and criminal justice policies, have largely been resolved, though they still refuse to provide details.

headline.main: By Now, the Budget Fight Isn't Really About the Budget

docs.snippet: More than half a year after Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his budget and precisely 14 weeks after the state's fiscal year began on April 1, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders can confidently agree on one thing: the longest budget fight in New York...

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing a torrent of criticism from health maintenance organizations, the Clinton Administration has temporarily shelved new rules that would have restricted the common H.M.O. practice of rewarding doctors who cut costs and control the use of services by Medicare and Medicaid patients. On March 27, the Administration issued rules to protect consumers by limiting the use of such financial incentives to reward doctors. But after the protests by H.M.O.'s, the Department of Health and Human Services quietly suspended enforcement of the rules, which are mandated by a 1990 law.

headline.main: U.S. SHELVES PLAN TO LIMIT REWARDS TO H.M.O. DOCTORS

docs.snippet: Facing a torrent of criticism from health maintenance organizations, the Clinton Administration has temporarily shelved new rules that would have restricted the common H.M.O. practice of rewarding doctors who cut costs and control the use of services...
